content.text: * Title: Human-Computer Interaction
* Code: CNTT1196
* Credits: 3 (45)
* Credit hours for teaching and learning activities:
+ Lecture: 25 hrs
+ Exercises in class: 10 hrs
+ Presentation and Discussion: 10 hrs
+ Self-study: 60 hrs
* Parallel course(s):
* Prerequisite course(s): CNTT11113
* Department conducting the course:
+ Faculty: Information Technology; Room 1310, Building A1, National Economics University; Phone number: 024.36280.280 (6334)
+ Lecturers:
1. MSc Pham Thao Tel: 0966986689 Email: thaop@neu.edu.vn
2. PhD Pham Xuan Lam Tel: 0937638683 Email: lapmpx@neu.edu.vn
3. MSc Tran Thi My Diep Tel: 0904335056 Email: diepttm@neu.edu.vn
* The course:
* Course language: In English
* Meeting hour: 8AM – 11AM on Wednesdays, Room 13.10, Building A1, National Economics University

Interaction between humans and computers is a complicated process with many rewards. Designing computer systems that are effective, efficient, easy to use, and enjoyable is important to realize the benefits of computation-based devices. The difficulties inherent in balancing the constraints of various aspects of human life create a complex web. The reward is the creation of digital libraries where scholars thousands of miles away can find and flip through virtual medieval manuscripts; medical instruments that enable a surgical team to design, locate and monitor a complex neurosurgical procedure; virtual worlds for entertainment and social interaction, responsive and efficient government services, from online license renewal to analysis of parliamentary testimonies; or smartphones that know where they are and understand limited language Interaction designers create meaningful interactions in virtual worlds and embed them seamlessly in physical worlds.

The goal of this subject is to introduce visual, gesture and speech interface technologies to students in Human Computer Interaction (HCI). We are focused on applications and services in intelligent environments and the personalized and context-sensitive interfaces that come with them. This course will teach you all you need to know about the user interface and software ergonomics.
[1] Dix A., Finlay J., Abowd G., and Beale R. Human-Computer Interaction, 3rd edition. Prentice Hall, Upper Saddle River, NJ, 2004.
[2] Scoot Klemmer. Human-Centered Design: An Introduction, Coursera course.
[3] John Wiley and Sons UK, Interaction Design: Beyond Human-Computer Interaction 4th Edition. 2015
[4] Stone, D., Jarrett, C., Woodroffe, M., & Minocha, S.: User interface design and evaluation. Morgan Kaufmann, 2005.
[5] Figma: https://www.figma.com/

content.text: Students are allowed to take the final exam if their attendance score reaches 5 points or more (on the scale of 10).

Students are responsible for attending all classes. In the case of absence from school due to force majeure reasons, sufficient and reasonable proofs must be provided. For each absence, 1 point will be deducted 1 point. Students who miss any classes more than 3 times, with or without reason, will be considered as failing to complete the course and have to re-register.
Students will be awarded points for constructive comments. These points are added to attendance points and group assignments.
Groups who do not submit the group work will receive a score of 0 (zero). Late submissions will be deducted for each day of late submission.
The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behavior that affects the teaching and learning process is strictly prohibited.

Students must come to class on time. Students who are late more than 10 minutes after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
Laptops and tablets are only used for the purpose of taking notes for and calculating for lectures and exercises, absolutely forbidden to use for other purposes.
